G.L. c. 186..proposition: Defendant Robert Smith is an individual who, upon information and belief, owns and/or controls the residential rental property located at 123 Main Street, Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts 02301 (the “Premises”), and is Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, as this is a civil action seeking money damages within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the Premises are located in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the claims arose in this county.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that any landlord or person acting on his behalf who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be liable for actual and consequential damages or for three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: The provision of “hot water” is an essential service required by the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.190, and the State Building Code, and constitutes a basic component of a habitable dwelling recognized under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Furthermore, under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and related case law, serious and continuing code violations and failures to provide essential services are recognized as interfering with tenants’ rights to a safe and habitable dwelling, reflecting public policy that landlords bear primary responsibility for habitability.

*Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway*,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 186, § 14, and the implied warranty of habitability recognized in *Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), residential landlords must provide essential services and maintain the premises in a habitable condition throughout the tenancy.
*Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway*,.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) expressly agrees that the common-law rule of no implied duty to keep premises fit is being reversed and that, at least for dwelling units, landlords have an obligation to comply with minimum habitability standards, derived from statutes and the State Sanitary Code, throughout the tenancy. It further endorses treating the landlord’s duty to provide and maintain premises meeting those standards and the tenant’s obligation to pay rent as mutually interdependent. Although the author criticizes the majority’s broader "implied warranty" framing, he clearly accepts that Massachusetts law now requires residential landlords to provide essential services and maintain habitability during the term.
*Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway*,.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule…that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’ … As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would…hold instead (a) that the various statutes…prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees…that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

*McKenna v. Begin*, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304.proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely restore hot water is not justified by his claim that a part is “backordered,” as Massachusetts law does not excuse a landlord’s statutory obligations based on supplier delays when an essential service such as hot water is unavailable for an extended period.
*McKenna v. Begin*, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and how to measure diminution in rental value; it does not discuss delays in restoring essential services, backordered parts, or any excuse for noncompliance based on supplier delays. There is no holding or reasoning about a landlord’s statutory duty to provide hot water, nor about whether supplier issues can justify an extended outage of an essential service. Accordingly, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*McKenna v. Begin*, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304.relevant_excerpt: One of the established aims of determining damages for breach of contract is to put the injured party in the position he would have been in if performance had been rendered as promised. … To fashion a measure of damages which more closely reflects the actual injury suffered by McKenna we adopt a percentage reduction of use approach, under which McKenna’s rent is to be reduced by a percentage reflecting the diminution in the value of the use and enjoyment of the leased premises by reason of the existence of defects which gave rise to the breach of warranty of habitability.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes an interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Apartment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, even if Defendant has communicated with Plaintiff and has claimed to be “working on” the repairs, because the statute is violated when there is a serious interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment by acts or omissions of the landlord or those acting under his control.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The case holds that a serious interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment caused by acts or omissions within the landlord’s control constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even without intent and even where the landlord has made some efforts but failed to correct the problem. Although the decision is about common‑law constructive eviction (not expressly G.L. c. 186, § 14), Massachusetts courts treat this reasoning as applicable to statutory quiet enjoyment: the focus is on the seriousness of the interference and the landlord’s control, not on promises to fix it. Thus, the opinion substantively supports the proposition’s principle, but only indirectly as to the statute.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

*Young v. Patrick*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 94.proposition: The absence of hot water for such a prolonged period, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, constitutes a violation of Plaintiff’s statutory right to quiet enjoyment even in the absence of willful harassment, because a substantial code violation that persists after notice and is attributable to the landlord’s failure to correct it supports liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Young v. Patrick*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 94.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a criminal appeal involving drug distribution and receiving stolen property. It does not concern landlord–tenant law, the State Sanitary Code, quiet enjoyment, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. Accordingly, it cannot support the proposition about lack of hot water and statutory quiet enjoyment rights; the citation appears to be to an entirely different case than the one whose text is reproduced here.
*Young v. Patrick*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 94.relevant_excerpt: The opinion contains no discussion of landlord-tenant law, sanitary code violations, hot water, or G.L. c. 186, § 14; it is entirely about criminal charges of distributing cocaine and receiving stolen property and related procedural issues.

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The absence of hot water for such a prolonged period, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, constitutes a violation of Plaintiff’s statutory right to quiet enjoyment even in the absence of willful harassment, because a substantial code violation that persists after notice and is attributable to the landlord’s failure to correct it supports liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that failure to provide required heat in violation of the State Sanitary Code is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that the landlord’s intent (including lack of willful harassment or financial inability) is not a defense; liability turns on the natural and probable consequences of the landlord’s conduct. While the facts concern lack of heat rather than hot water, the reasoning is framed broadly around sanitary code heat requirements and quiet enjoyment, and thus supports the proposition by close analogy.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The tenant correctly argues that the judge erred in declaring that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil constituted a defense to the quiet enjoyment claim. A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Gomes v. Fair*, 738 F.3d 509, 514\u2013.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that a tenant’s covenant of quiet enjoyment protects the tenant’s right to freedom from serious and substantial interference with the tenancy caused by the landlord or by others whose conduct the landlord has a legal obligation to control.
*Gomes v. Fair*, 738 F.3d 509, 514\u2013.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Second Circuit § 1983 prisoner excessive-force/statute-of-limitations decision. It does not involve Massachusetts law, landlord-tenant relationships, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, it cannot be authority for the Massachusetts tenant quiet-enjoyment principle described in the proposition.

*Doe v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 404 Mass..proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy substantial violations of the State Sanitary Code or to provide essential services after notice can constitute a constructive eviction or a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 404 Mass..support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a products-liability and consortium decision involving an industrial machine injury; it does not concern landlord–tenant law, the State Sanitary Code, essential services, constructive eviction, or breach of quiet enjoyment. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses habitability standards or the effect of a landlord’s failure to repair code violations. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the stated landlord-tenant proposition.
*Doe v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 404 Mass..relevant_excerpt: No portion of the provided text discusses landlords, tenants, the State Sanitary Code, essential services, constructive eviction, or quiet enjoyment; the opinion focuses on product design, duty to warn, motions to amend, and loss of consortium in a workplace injury context.

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Courts applying § 14 have recognized that when code violations or serious service failures persist over time, even absent overt harassment, tenants are entitled to statutory damages.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for persistent code violations or serious service failures, even without overt harassment. Young v. Patukonis does not involve § 14 at all; the opinion addresses sanitary code obligations, security deposit treble damages under § 15B, rent-control remedies, warranty of habitability, and c. 93A. Because § 14 is never mentioned and no statutory-damages analysis is conducted under that provision, this case does not support the claimed proposition.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Courts applying § 14 have recognized that when code violations or serious service failures persist over time, even absent overt harassment, tenants are entitled to statutory damages.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case is a warranty-of-habitability and rent-abatement decision; it does not involve G. L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it discuss statutory damages for code violations or service failures under that statute. The court affirms a common-law rent abatement remedy based on strict warranty liability, focusing on when rent abates after notice, not on statutory damages in the absence of harassment. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for how courts applying § 14 treat persistent code violations or service failures.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “When the tenant’s loss of heat occurred, G. L. c. 239, § 8A, permitted the tenant to withhold rent for Code violations only if ‘the owner . . . had not taken reasonable steps to remedy such conditions.’ … As was the case in Hemingway, this statute provides for rent withholding, not rent abatement; but, as in Hemingway, we choose to permit a rent abatement as a matter of common law.”

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Courts applying § 14 have recognized that when code violations or serious service failures persist over time, even absent overt harassment, tenants are entitled to statutory damages.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case discusses the covenant and statutory right of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does so only to affirm that no breach occurred and that there was no interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The court does not award statutory damages, nor does it recognize that persistent code violations or serious service failures alone (in the absence of harassment) entitle tenants to statutory damages. Instead, it finds the landlord acted promptly and that the conditions did not amount to a violation, which is contrary to the proposition claimed.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. … The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”}
